Ane Ballat of y? Captane of the Castell. 1571. At þe castle of Edinburch, Vpoun þe bank baith greine & rouch, As myne alone I lay, With paper, pen, and inke in hand, Musing, as I could vnderst?d, Off þe suddan decay, That vnto þis puir natiune Apeirandly dois come, I fand o? Congregatione Was caus of all and some, Whois aucthoris, instructoris, Hes blindit þame so long, That blameles & shameles Both riche & pour they wrong. These wicked vaine venerianis, Proud poysoned Pharisianes With thair blind guydis but grace, Hes caused þe puire cuntrie Assist vnto þair traitorie, Thair prince for to displace: For teine I can not testifie How wr?gouslie þey wrocht, When þai þair Prince so pitiouslie In prisone strong had brocht, Abused hir, accused hir With serpent wordis fell Of schavelis and rebellis, Like hiddeous hound? of hell. These despaired bird? of Beliall Tho? no? but to advance þam sell, Fra þai had hir down throwin, With errore and hypocrisie, To c?mitt open traitorie, As cleirlie now is knowin: But þe grit God ?nipotent, That secreit thochtis dois serche, Releivit hes þat innocent Out of þair rage so fearce; Provydet and guyded Hir to ane vncouth land, Whair wander & scl?der With enemeis none sho fand. Sen tyme of which ejectione, This cuntrie is c?e in subjectione And daylie seruitud, With men of weir in garisone, To the co?ones oppressione, By slicht & suddrone bloud; Whose craft, ingyne, & polycie, Full reddy bent is euer, Be treasone vnder amitie, Our nobles to disseaver: Some rubbing, some budding, Thair studie þai employ, That slichtlie, vnrichtlie, They may þis realme ?joy. This guyding gart grit greif aryse In me, wha nawayis culd devyis To mend þis grit misch?ce; And, als I argoued all þe cais, I hard ane say w?in þis place: “With help of God & Fr?ce I sall, within ane litill space, Thy dolouris all to drese; With help of Christ þow sall, or Pasche, Thy kyndlie Prince posses: Detrusaris, refuisaris Off hir authoritie, None cairand or spairand, Shall outher die or flie. “Thought God, of his just jugm?t, Thole þaim to be ane punishment To hir, þair supreme heid, ?it, sen þey war particip?t With hir, & sho now penit?t, Richt suirly þey may dreid: As wicked scourges hes bene seine Get for þe scourgene hyre, When synneris repentis from þe splene, The scourge cast in þe fyre; Swa Mortone, be fortone, May get þis same reward: His boasting, nor posting, I doe it not reguard. “Baith him & all þair c?pany, Thocht England wald þaim fortifie, I cair thaim nocht a leike: ffor all þair grit munitione, I am in suire tuitione: This hauld it sall me keip. My realme & Princes libertie Thairin I sall defend, When traitouris salbe hangit hie, Or make some sch?full end. Assuire þame, I cuire þame Evin as þei do deserve; Thair tressone, þis cessone, It sall not make me suerve: “ffor I haue men & meit aneugh, They know I am ane tuil?eour teoch, And wilbe rycht sone greved: When þei haue tint als mony teith, As þei did at þe seige of Leith, They wilbe faine to leive it. Then quha, I pray ?ou, salbe boun Thair tinsall to advance? Or gif sic compositione As þei got þen of France? This sylit, begylit, They will bot get þe glaik?; Cum þai heir, þir tuo yeir, They sall not misse þair paik?. “As for my ny?bo??? Edinburch toun, What salbe thair pairt, vp or downe, I can not ?it declair; Bot one thing I make manifest, Gif þei me ony thing molest, Þair buithis salbe maid bair. Gif fyre may þair buildings sacke, Or bullat beat þaim downe, They sall nocht faill þat end to mak The staires made in þis toun. Swa vse þaim, and chuse þaim, What pairt þei will ensew; Forsake me, or take me, They sall drink as þei brew.” He bade me rise & muse na mair, Bot pray to God, both lait & aire, To saue þis noble ludge, Which is, in all prosperitie, And lykwayis in aduersitie, Our Princes plane refuge. Thairfoir all trew men I exhort, That ?e with me accord, That we all, baith in ernest & sport, Aske at þe leving Lord, That hanged, or manged, Mot ilk m? mak his end, Wha dewlie & trewlie Wald nocht þis house defend. Finis.
